newsitem.title: CONGO: Portuguese troops in Congo for Zaire evacuation.
newsitem.headline: Portuguese troops in Congo for Zaire evacuation.

text.p: A contingent of 76 Portuguese soldiers joined other Western troops in the Congo capital to await a possible evacuation of nationals from Zaire, diplomats said.

The diplomats said the Portuguese arrived aboard a French military Lockheed C-130 transport aircraft on Wednesday night at the international airport in Brazzaville, only three km (two miles) across the Zaire river from Kinshasa.
Laurent Kabila's rebels are no more than 200 km (125 miles) away and have threatened to attack the teeming city of five million if President Mobutu Sese Seko does not resign.
As much as a rebel assault, residents fear Mobutu's army may go on the rampage in Kinshasa, as it did in 1991 and 1993.
Mobutu went to Gabon on Thursday for a mini-summit with a handful of fellow French-speaking West African presidents to try and find a peaceful end to the civil war.

Some 400 Portuguese live in Kinshasa, mainly businessmen and their families. In the event of an evacuation they would head for designated "welcome centres" from where they would be taken to the Portuguese embassy.
Any decision to evacuate Portuguese nationals would follow a signal from the Portuguese ambassador in Kinshasa and final word from the defence and foreign ministries in Lisbon.
Troops from France, Zaire's former colonial ruler Belgium, the United States and Britain have spent weeks in Brazzaville waiting to step into Kinshasa and pull out nationals if the need arises.
The United States rotated fresh marines into Central Africa at the weekend and urged its nationals to leave Zaire.
Thousands of Europeans and North Americans live in Kinshasa, most of them French and Belgians.
